column4: Hey all so is anyone here fairly decent with wifi connections and Feisty Fawn?
Do you know what your wifi card is?
it's a WMP54G running a RaLink RT61
What is the problem?
The network is unencrypted and should be easy to find and select, however even when the OS claims to be connected (even showing 4 out of 5 signal bars), I can't even ping my default gateway
run ifconfig and see if you have an ip address
I have no problems, but I'm running on a 5 year old PowerBook.... apple's original Airport card was based on the prism2 chipset which is widely understood and supported under linux

I don't know.  Sounds like the problem is related to dhcp and dhcp is one area where I'm fuzzy on linux.  There are about 3 different clients, but manually working them is something I don't know of f the top of my head
Have you tried manually setting an ip, etc?

yes... I followed an entire manual configuration guide - everything set until I got to the point where I defined my default gateway, and the terminal returned that it couldn't find the host on the network... sad considering the gw IS the network :P
I did find this: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=132980
that's another one that I followed... the problem is that the FAQ there is for Breezy 5.10 and a few of the folders that it references have disappeared from feisty
/lib/modules/`uname -r`/kernel/drivers/net/, and this command $ sudo mkdir /etc/Wireless/RT61STA/ completely fails in feisty
i've read another FAQ that claimed that the thread you found simply doesn't work on feisty http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t-419709
that address again was http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=419709
This post is more related to Fiesty Fawn... http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=415693
how is your network setup?  Just the AP connected to dsl/cable modem?

Thanks for that link I'll try that in a bit... As for network setup I truly don't know - it's a service provided by my university for use in the dorms, and has been a bit of a nightmare. The system is an open network that when first accessed leads IE/Firefox to a login page... I assume that I can still use the same system in linux but maybe not ...?

is it possible that it uses PEEP/LEAP/whatever.  I'm not exactly sure what those are, but I think they wifi authentication methods.  Some UNis use them, and I've heard of troubles with linux and even getting osx working on them.

I know for a fact osx works great on it... i truly don't know it's a real nightmare either way... but even on windows before accessing the login page the server assigns me an IP address - you would think it would do the same for linux
thanks for all the help I'm going to try that last link... if it doesn't work then i'm going to hit the pit. Thanks man! Peace to everyone!
